questions.question: Which of the following is used in immunohistochemical (IHC) staining as a chromogen to diagnose tumours of unknown origin?
questions.explanation: ′ Diaminobenzidine(DAB) is a chromogen used in histochemical and IHC staining. In IHC, DAB is a substrate for a peroxidase enzyme coupled to a primary or secondary antibody. It is oxidised and converted to an insoluble polymer, precipitating as a dark brown pigment, which allows visualisation of the target molecule. Congo red can stain amyloid fibres in red and orange. When viewed under polarised light in a microscope, Congo-red-stained tissues high in amyloid will show bright apple-green birefringence (Option 2). Masson's Trichrome stains collagen fibres blue. It can identify cardiac fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic kidney disease (Option 3). Mucicarmine stains mucin, a secretion produced in epithelial and connective tissue and capsule of Cryptococcus (Option 4). Reference: 3,3 ′ -Diaminobenzidine staining interferes with PCR-based DNA analysis - PMC (nih.gov) Histology, Staining - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: Which of the following is a marker for breast cancer? D. β - HCG
questions.explanation: Biochemical assays targeting tumour-associated enzymes, hormones, and other markers in the bloodstream often lack the sensitivity and specificity to diagnose cancer definitively. However, when used alongside other diagnostic tests, they can aid in identifying cancer. Additionally, these assays prove valuable in monitoring a tumour's response to treatment and detecting tumour recurrence. Tumor marker Associated conditions Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) Hepatoblastoma Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour) Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13 β -HCG (Option D) Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma) Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) Colorectal cancer Pancreatic cancer Breast cancer Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers) Gastric cancer Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) Prostate cancer Benign prostatic hyperplasia Prostatitis Calcitonin Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2) Alkaline phosphatase Metastases to bone or liver Paget disease of the bone Placental alkaline phosphatase Seminoma Lactate dehydrogenase Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma) Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma) Lymphomas Ewing's sarcoma Neuron specific enolase (NSE) Neuroendocrine tumors Small cell lung cancer Carcinoid tumour Neuroblastoma CA 19–9 (Option A) Pancreatic adenocarcinoma Colon cancer Cholangiocarcinoma CA 15–3 and CA 27–29 Breast cancer CA 125 (Option B) Ovarian carcinoma Other gynecologic malignancies S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B) Malignant melanoma SMRP Mesothelioma Reference: Robbins pathology, 10th edition, Pg 336.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to determine treatment response in patients with colorectal cancer?
questions.explanation: associated with colon, pancreas, stomach, and breast carcinoma . CEA can be used to assess responsiveness to treatment in colorectal cancers. Successful resection of the underlying tumour results in markers such as CEA disappearing from the serum. The persistent elevation of CEA post-resection warrants further investigation into the presence of the underlying tumor. Alpha-fetoprotein ( Option 1): Alpha-fetoprotein is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma and yolk sac tumours. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin ( Option 3): Human Chorionic gonadotropin is associated with choriocarcinoma. Calcitonin ( Option 4): Calcitonin is a tumor marker for Medullary thyroid carcinoma. Reference: Robbins pathology, 10th edition, 335,336.

questions.question: What needle size is typically employed for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) procedures?
questions.explanation: FNAC procedures is the 25-27-gauge needle. This ensures effective sample retrieval while minimising patient discomfort and mitigating tissue trauma. FNAC: FNAC is a minimally invasive technique for procuring cells from suspicious lesions or masses for cytological examination. It utilises a slender needle gauge to extract cells from the target site. In the FNAC procedure, the lesion of interest is first identified via imaging modalities such as ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI. A needle is then inserted into the lesion, and gentle suction is applied to draw cells into a syringe. Multiple passes may be made to ensure a sufficient sample volume. The material is either smeared onto glass slides or preserved in a fixative solution for subsequent cytological analysis. Reference: Robbins pathology, 10th edition, Pg 331. Optimal needle size for thyroid fine needle aspiration cytology - PubMed (nih.gov)

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is FNAC helpful in establishing diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D ) Medullary thyroid carcinoma Explanation: FNAC is an initial investigation in the diagnosis of the medullary adenoma of the thyroid and other thyroid disorders. It is not particularly useful in establishing the diagnosis of follicular lesions as the follicular adenoma and carcinoma appear similar on fnac, and the architecture of the gland is not visible. Limitations of FNAC: Cystic changes cannot be identified. Inadequate cell sampling may require repeated procedure Indications Contraindications /limitations Thyroid disorders Follicular disorders of the thyroid (Limitation) (Option A ruled out) Breast lesions Infections, septicemia Lymph node evaluation Bleeding disorders Pancreatic malignancy Hydatid cyst- Risk of anaphylaxis (Option C ruled out) Most solid organ masses accessible via FNAC Testicular cancer- Increased risk of spread of cancer (Option B ruled out) Reference: Robbins pathology, 10th edition, Pg 331. Fine Needle Aspiration - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Problems and limitations with fine needle aspiration cytology of solitary thyroid nodules - PubMed (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with a breast lump. On biopsy, the tissue shows anaplastic cells without any differentiation. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining is performed to characterise the tumour further. Which marker would be most appropriate to confirm the epithelial origin of the tumour cells in breast cancer?
questions.explanation: the epithelial origin of the tumour cells in breast cancer. CK 7 is also positive in the ovary, lung, pancreaticobiliary and stomach epithelial tumours . ER (estrogen receptor), PR (progesterone receptor), and HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) are other markers that can be positive in breast cancer, which help in deciding management. CD19 and CD20 are markers expressed on B cells , not epithelial cells. They are commonly used in the diagnosis of B-cell lymphomas. Notably, CK20 is a marker of epithelial origin expressed in colon cancer ( Option 1) p63 is a marker positive in squamous cell carcinoma in the lung ( Option 2) TTF-1(thyroid transcription factor-1) is a marker positive in the adenocarcinoma of the lung (Option 3) Reference: Robbins Pathology 10th edition - Pg- 993, 719, 593, 1056,718 Panels of immunohistochemical markers help determine primary sites of metastatic adenocarcinoma - PubMed (nih.gov)

questions.question: Match the given neoplasias with their respective immunohistochemistry markers. 1. Carcinoma A. S100 2. Sarcoma B. Leucocyte common antigen 3. Lymphoma C. Cytokeratin 4. Melanoma D. Vimentin
questions.explanation: their respective immunohistochemistry(IHC) markers are 1. Carcinoma(epithelial origin/squamous cell carcinoma) Cytokeratin Cytokeratin 1, cytokeratin 10 2. Sarcoma Vimentin, desmin(skeletal muscle) 3. Lymphoma Leucocyte common antigen, CD 45 4. Melanoma S100, HMB45,Melan A IHC markers are used to identify undifferentiated tumours. The tissues are fixed with these stains, and the origin of the tumour is determined by the positive reaction to markers shown by these cells. questions.question: A 60-year-old male was diagnosed with a lung malignancy two months ago. He now came with complaints of malaise, abdominal pain, bone pain, lethargy, and confusion. The intern suspects a condition related to lung cancer and decides to send a blood test. Which of the following would be the appropriate test?
questions.explanation: suggests a diagnosis of paraneoplastic syndrome of hypercalcemia associated with lung cancer. The appropriate test to diagnose this is parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHRP). Paraneoplastic syndrome: The paraneoplastic syndrome refers to signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the tumour's anatomic distribution or hormones indigenous to the tumour tissue. These occur in about 10% of patients with cancer It may be the earliest manifestation of an occult neoplasm. It may mimic metastatic disease and confound treatment. PTHRP leads to hypercalcemia, which can present as Nausea, vomiting, Abdominal pain( groans) , Bone pain( bones) , Renal stones( stones) , Fatigue malaise (moans) , Polyuria, polydipsia, Constipation( thrones) , Lethargy, confusion, depression, Memory loss ( psychic overtones ). PTHRP is also associated with Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung Breast carcinoma Renal carcinoma Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma Erythropoietin levels can be checked in polycythemia, which associated with renal carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioma, and hepatocellular carcinoma ( Option 1). Adrenocorticotrophic hormone(ACTH) levels can be checked in Cushing’s syndrome which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung, pancreatic carcinoma, and neural tumours ( Option 2). Antidiuretic hormone levels can be checked in Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion(SIADH) which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung and intracranial neoplasms ( Option 4). Reference: Robbins Pathology 10th edition: Page no 328-329 Hypercalcemia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndrome is not associated with lung cancer?
questions.explanation: neoplasms and not lung cancer. questions.question: An appendix specimen, whose HPE is shown below, had a 2 cm submucosal nodule identified. Electron microscopy showed numerous neurosecretory granules in the cytoplasm. Twenty-four-hour urine analysis showed an elevation of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: uniform round nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma, suggest a carcinoid tumor (a.k.a Argentaffinoma). It typically has bronchoconstriction, not bronchodilation. Image showing cells arranged in the form of rosette (cells in nests) Image showing salt and pepper chromatin Carcinoid tumors: Derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin. It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver. It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins. These mediators are usually metabolised by the liver, so patients are initially asymptomatic. With progression and hepatic metastasis, there is Diarrhoea and abdominal cramping- increased motility and excessive secretion due to serotonin (intermittent diarrhoea) (Option 2) Flushing and pruritus due to histamine (Option 1) Wheezing and dyspnea due to bronchospasm Pellagra(diarrhoea, dermatitis, dementia): Secondary to niacin deficiency as tryptophan is diverted to the serotonin synthesis Carcinoid heart disease: Tricuspid regurgitation leading to right heart failure (Option 3) Diagnosis: Elevated twenty-four-hour urine for 5-HIAA Elevated serum serotonin Elevated serum chromogranin A Octreoscan for localising the source
